importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on October 21, 2025, marking the latest update on the Reefline project's development and public awareness.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Reefline project is estimated to take at least a decade to complete, with full realization expected by around 2035.

keyTakeAways: Reefline is a 7-mile-long artificial reef being developed off Miami Beach, combining marine art and ecological restoration.
The project features underwater sculptures, including 22 concrete cars, designed to serve as coral substrates and habitats.
Coral species, such as gorgonians, are cultivated in nurseries and will be transplanted to the reef to restore and revitalize marine ecosystems.
The reef will be accessible to swimmers in 15–20 feet of water, 700 feet off Miami Beach, without requiring boats.
The project is partially funded by a $5 million city bond and aims to raise $6 million more for its first phase.
Artists like Leandro Ehrlich and curator Ximena Caminos are central to the project, blending art, science, and environmental restoration.
Reefline aims to restore a historical coral reef that was lost due to beach sand replenishment in the 1970s.
The project includes an onshore marine learning center to educate the public on coral reef conservation.
A future phase will feature 57 giant sculpted starfish, potentially becoming a symbol of Miami Beach.
The project represents a fusion of art, science, and sustainability, promoting ecotourism and reef resilience.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Reefline, a 7-mile-long artificial reef being developed off Miami Beach, combines marine art and ecological restoration to revive a once-lost coral reef. Led by artists and scientists like Ximena Caminos and Colin Foord, the project features underwater sculptures—such as concrete cars and starfish—designed to host resilient coral species like gorgonians. These corals will grow over time, transforming the sculptures into vibrant, living reefs. The project is funded by a $5 million city bond and aims to raise $6 million more, with full completion expected in about a decade. It will be accessible to swimmers in shallow water (15–20 feet), 700 feet off the beach, and includes an onshore education center. Reefline not only restores ecological balance but also creates a unique ecotourism and cultural landmark, with potential symbolic value for Miami Beach.
title: Miami Beach puts the art in offshore artificial reef
